newsitem.title: USA: Cleveland stadium COPs issue set for March.
newsitem.headline: Cleveland stadium COPs issue set for March.

text.p: Cleveland plans to sell $130 million to $140 million of certificates of participation in March to help finance a new football stadium, the city's finance director said Friday.
Martin Carmody said the COPs would be paid off with revenues from taxes on parking, admissions and car rentals. A.G. Edwards & Sons has been selected to lead the deal, he added.
Carmody said the COPs deal would be the last debt issuance by the city for the project.
In October, Cleveland sold $15 million of bond anticipation notes to fund demolition of Municipal Stadium, the former home of the Cleveland Browns football team, to make way for the new stadium.
Carmody said the upcoming COPs issue may or may not be used take out the BANs.
The remainder of the stadium, currently estimated to cost $242 million, would be funded mainly with a contribution by the National Football League and a state of Ohio grant.
While the city has yet to get a replacement for its former Browns team now in Baltimore, Carmody said luxury seat sales have been going well.
